column4: if an application makes my screen resolution bigger in order to work but then it crashes and leaves the screen with that resolution making it impossible for me to use, how do i find and kill what is causing? (ps aux | grep ??) or how do i simply put it back as it was, yesterday i tried many things from tt1 but in the end i had to reboot, i'd like to avoid it. any idea? thanks
first, run xrandr in a terminal, and find out how to change modes with that. Then assign your favorite resolution to a gnome shortcut, e.g. alt+ctrl+1 ==> 1280x800.
so u think even without closing the application thatz causing the problem i can reassign the resolution i want?
yes
ok cool, also i wasnt able to use my mouse, the keyboard i could use but just for writing in the quarter of screen i was able to see at that resolution
try it, and if you get stuck anywhere ping me
alright thanks, can i do it from tt1 or it has to be from a terminal?
you need to be in an x session when you do it
so you can't do it from vt1. E.g. from withing the problematic app, you just press alt+ctrl+1.
(not alt+ctrl+F1 - I mean the shortcut that you put to change resolution)
isnt tt1 one? (is the second command u suggested ctrl + alt + "number one" or "letter l" cuz in case itz an L i use that combo to lock the screen
ok let me change the example shortcut: With you assign "alt+ctrl+r" to xrandr --output default --mode 1280x800. Then within the game, you just press alt+ctrl+r.
xrandr only gives me this http://paste.ubuntu.com/274565/ how do i change key-shortcuts and stuff?
first, try to change resolutions: xrandr --output default --mode 1360x768
Does it work? Then, put the resolution back with: xrandr --output default --mode 1360x768
is the same command :D
sorry, I meant put the resolution back with xrandr --output default --mode 1440x900
it does work but look http://paste.ubuntu.com/274569/
well, if it works you can just ignore your graphics card module errors ;) Now, to assign a shortcut... do you have compiz enabled or not?
yep

there's a settings editor for compiz, but I don't use compiz so I don't remember its name. That settings editors has a panel with the shortcut editor. There you can put the "custom command" I think it supports up to 12 of them. I have 12 different resolutions with alt+ctrl+something shortcuts ... :)
